solution.em: ( Instructor solution preview: show the student solution after due date. )
solution.p: The degree of f(x) is 3\text{,} as that is the number of linear factors. So, its end-behavior is the same as x^3\text{.}

A linear function and an exponential function are graphed below. Find possible formulas for the functions f(t), in blue, and g(t), in red, that go through the points (5,26) and (25,8).

static.solution:
( Instructor solution preview: show the student solution after due date. )
SOLUTION
a) Assuming f(t) is linear, we have f(t)=b+mt where f(5)=26 and f(25)=8. This gives
m = \frac{f(25)-f(5)}{25-5}=\frac{-18}{20}.
Solving for b, we have
f(5) = b - (18/20)5
b=f(5)+(18/20)5=26+(18/20)5=30.5
so f(t)=30.5-(18/20) t.
b) Assuming g(t) is exponential, we have g(t)=ab^t, where g(5)=26 and g(25)= 8. Using the ratio method, we have
\frac{ab^{25}}{ab^{5}} = \frac{g(25)}{g(5)}
b^{20} = \frac{8}{26}
b = \left( \frac{8}{26} \right)^{1/20} \approx 0.9428 .
Now solve for a:
a(0.9428)^{5} = 26
a = \frac{26}{(0.9428)^5} \approx 34.9095.
so g(t)= 34.9095 (0.9428)^{t}.

statement.p: Find a possible formula for the exponential function through the points (0,6) and (2,96) graphed below.

static.solution:
( Instructor solution preview: show the student solution after due date. )
SOLUTION
If the function is exponential, its formula is of the form y=ab^x. Since (0,6) is on the graph when x = 0, y = ab^0 = a = 6.
Using the other point at (2,96) we can solve for b:
y = ab^x = 6(b)^2 = 96 so b^2 = 96/6 = 16 and b = (16)^{1/2} = 4
The formula is therefore y = 6(4)^x.

statement.p: Find a value a >0 so that the graph of the exponential function f(x)=a^x contains the point (3,1/8).

static.solution:
( Instructor solution preview: show the student solution after due date. )
SOLUTION
Regression on a calculator returns the exponential function g(x) = 7 (1.7)^{x}.

statement.p: Find a possible formula for the exponential function through the points (-2,18) and (1,2/3) graphed below.

static.solution:
( Instructor solution preview: show the student solution after due date. )
SOLUTION
If the function is exponential, its formula is of the form y=ab^x. The points (-2,18) and (1,2/3) are on the graph so,
18 = ab^{-2}
\frac{2}{3} = ab^{1}
Taking the ratio of the second equation to the first one we have
\frac{2/3}{18} = \frac{ab^1}{ab^-2}
\frac{1}{27} = b^3
b = \frac{1}{3}.
Substituting this value of b into the second equation gives
\frac{2}{3} = a \left( \frac{1}{3} \right)^1
a = 2
Thus, y = 2 \left( \frac{1}{3} \right)^x.
